attributes.title: Political Consequences of COVID-19 Pandemic
attributes.description: This research project briefly aims to expand on the existing research on how risk perception during COVID-19 pandemic social dynamics effect people’s support for political measures. In this research, we focus to reveal social predictors of support for restrictive policies regarding civil liberties

q1.value: Huseyin Cakal, Darío Páez, José J. Pizarro Carrasco, Nekane Basabe, Larraitz Nerea Zumeta Sánchez, Marcela Gracia, Saeed Keshavarzi, Nebojsa Petrovic, Илья Ягияев, Lander Méndez

q2.value:
H1: Self isolation will be negatively associated with collective resilience and collective narcissism 
H2: Socio Economic Status (SES) will be positively associated with collective resilience and collective narcissism
H3: National Identification will be positively associated with collective resilience and collective narcissism
H4: Collective Resilience will be negatively associated with Support for martial law and support for restriction of civil liberties.
H5: Collective Resilience will be positively associated with collective efficacy.
H6: Narcissism will be positively associated with Support for martial law and support for restriction of civil liberties.
H7: Narcissism will be positively associated with collective efficacy.
H8: Collective efficacy will be negatively associated with Support for martial law and support for restriction of civil liberties.
Model 2 Hypotheses
H1: SDO will be negatively associated with breakdown of leadership, hopelessness, and helplessness. 
H2: SDO will be positively associated with breakdown of social fabric
H3: RWA will be negatively associated with breakdown of leadership.
H4: RWA will be positively associated with breakdown of social fabric, hopelessness, and helplessness
H5: Breakdown of Leadership will be positively associated with support for strong leadership and support for restrictive policies (martial law, restriction of civil liberties). 
H6: Breakdown of social fabric will be positively associated with support for strong leadership and support for restrictive policies (martial law, restriction of civil liberties).
H7: Hopelessness will be positively associated with support for strong leadership and support for restrictive policies (martial law, restriction of civil liberties).
H7: Helplessness will be positively associated with support for strong leadership and support for restrictive policies (martial law, restriction of civil liberties).
H8: Breakdown of Social Fabric, Breakdown of Leadership, Hopelessness, and helplessness will be negatively associated with evaluation of government/ satisfaction

Model 3
H1:  Representations of blaming others (Covid and eating bats) will be positively associated with perceptions of higher vulnerability, low control and anxiety, and RWA.
H2:  Representations of blaming others (Covid and eating bats) will be positively associated with will be positively associated with collective narcissism and SDO.
H3:  Conspiracy representations (Covid as bacteriological weapon; "solution" for the older) will be positively associated with perceptions of higher vulnerability, low control and anxiety, and RWA.
H4:  Representations of Elite villains (pharmaceutical multinational benefits; political corrupt elite impedes fight with COVID) positively associated with perceptions of higher vulnerability, low control and anxiety, and RWA.
H5:  Representations of Elite underdog villains (mass crazy; lack of self-control individual deserves to be infected) will be positively associated with collective narcissism and SDO.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Impact of Task Analysis Smart Phone App on Employment Skills for Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities
attributes.description: The proposed multiple baseline design study will investigate the impact of a Task Analysis smart phone application, which utilized video and audio prompting, with four young adults with intellectual disabilities (ID) on the completion of common work-related office tasks.

q1.value: The Impact of a Task Analysis Smart Phone App on Improving Work Performance of Individuals with Intellectual Disabilities

q2.value: Joseph Ryan, Jordan Stierle, Sharon Walters, Alex Carlson, Daniel Stockwell

q3.value: Individuals with intellectual disabilities (ID) often experience a combination of both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits that impact conceptual, social, and practical domains. These deficits can negatively impact an individual’s ability to achieve independence and sustained employment. Research has shown that assistive technology (AT) can help support employment skills for individuals with ID. The proposed multiple baseline design study will investigate the impact of a Task Analysis smart phone application, which utilized video and audio prompting, with four young adults with ID on the completion of common work-related office tasks.

q4.value: The purpose of this study is to examine the effectiveness of a highly customizable iPhone Task Analysis application that utilizes a combination of video including picture, text, audio support, video prompting, and video modeling feature, as a mechanism to complete assigned novel office tasks independently and efficiently.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Multiple Baseline Design Across Subjects

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Participants included four young adults with ID attending a four-year post-secondary education (PSE) program that is housed on a medium sized public university located in the southeastern United States. The program provides an integrated course of study for 40 students with ID to enhance independent living and employment skills. Selection criteria for participants required that they: (a) be enrolled in the PSE program designed for young adults with ID, (b) have a diagnosis of moderate ID (36 – 51 IQ), and (c) not capable of successfully performing common office related tasks measured, which included laminating, creating organized folders, and mailings.

q14.value: This is a single case research design.

question.value: Students will be provided an iPhone 6 with Task Analysis Lite application software that can be downloaded for free through the Apple Store. This software breaks complex tasks into individual steps by providing students with a picture, audio, and video delivery for each step of the task. The app also has a feature called the overall video mode which combines all individual step recordings into one continuous video to display the task analysis in its entirety. The researchers developed separate task analyses for three common office-related tasks including shredding paper, copying documents, and scanning documents. Each task analysis consists of 10 steps of similar levels of difficulty. Tasks will be broken into their individual steps and then recorded sequentially using the Task Analysis app. Each step of the task analysis includes the following three components: (a) directions for the individual step, (b) a picture of the completed step, and (c) recording of a researcher completing that step, while reading the directions for the step aloud. Using the Task Analysis app on the iPhone, participants will be able to view the step-by-step task analysis for each office task. Participants will have the option of watching the overall video or click on each individual step. Individual steps include text directions, video, and audio of the step being completed. Participants have the option of replaying individual steps at any time.

Data recording.  During each trial, data will be collected by researchers regarding the number of steps completed independently and correctly by each participant. Responses will  only be scored as correct if the participant (a) completes the step accurately, (b) does not receive any prompting, and (c) the step is completed in the proper sequential order. At the end of each session, data will be entered into an Excel spreadsheet and converted to a percentage by dividing the number of steps completed by the total number of steps and then multiplying by 100. Data points will then be graphed.

Effects of the Task Analysis app on student ability to complete common office work tasks will be examined using a combination of visual analysis and calculation of effect sizes between baseline and the intervention condition. To measure study effects of each student, a visual analysis of the graphed data was completed. This technique allows for analysis of changes in level, trend, variability, immediacy of the effect, overlap, and consistency of data patterns across similar phases. Specific guidelines for visually analyzing SCRD outlined in Kratochwill et al. (2010) will be followed. 

Effect Size Calculation: Tau U. Tau U has become one of the more commonly used measures of effect size today due to its nonparametric approach (Morash-MacNeil et al., 2017; Parker, Vannest, Davis, & Sauber, 2011). Tau-U is derived from Kendall’s and Mann-Whitney U (see Parker et al., 2011) and is calculated by merging trend and nonoverlap data.

q21.value: Tau-U effects are measured as small (0–0.65), medium (0.66–0.92), and large (0.93–1.00), which are equivalent to ranges recommended for nonoverlap of all pairs (Parker, Vannest, & Brown, 2009).

q22.value: All data will be included in the Results.

attributes.title: The Effects of Non-Food Item Vouchers in a Humanitarian Context The Case of the Rapid Response to Movements of Population Program in Congo

q1.value: The Effects of Non-Food Item Vouchers in a Humanitarian Context The Case of the Rapid Response to Movements of Population Program in Congo

q2.value: John Quattrochi | Ghislain Bisimwa | Maarten Voors | Peter Van der Windt

q5.value: We would like to thank Tyler Thompson for excellent research assistance and Alexandra Blason, Yannick Brand, Gabriele Erba, Mia Jeong, Steven Michel, Pacifique Mugaruka, Anna Orlanidni, Aude Rigot, and Frederic Unterreiner at UNICEF for their comments and

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In 2015, across the globe, an estimated 65 million people were forcibly displaced, and a total of $28 billion was spent on international humanitarian assistance (GHA, 2016). Despite the vast sum of money spent each year, little evidence exists on the effectiveness of emergency aid. Research on humanitarian assistance is challenging as it must overcome security concerns, logistical hurdles, a relative paucity of high quality monitoring data, and the urgency of humanitarian action. At the same time, there is an increasing demand from donors, policy-makers and implementing agencies to know what works and why, as this is directly linked to the efficient use of limited resources to achieve development outcomes. In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), humanitarian actors have been present for over 20 years in response to on-going armed conflict and low state capacity in the mountainous east of the country. Acute crises such as population displacement and natural disasters exacerbate a situation of chronic vulnerability, especially among the rural population. As of May 2017, the IDMC estimated that ongoing conflicts in North and South Kivu and an increase in inter-communal clashes in southern and central regions such as Tanganyika, the Kasais, Ituri and Uele, had caused 922,000 people to be displaced from their homes, with an additional 130,000 displaced due to natural disasters over the course of 2016 alone. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) estimates there are some 3.8 million Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in DRC as of May 2017, the highest number in Africa. Most of these IDPs lack sufficient access to food, clean water, and sanitation facilities, and threats to security are pervasive. Similar conditions hold even for most non-displaced rural populations in the east. In May 2014, the International Initiative for Impact Evaluation (3ie), in partnership with the DRC Humanitarian Pooled Fund (HPF), requested qualifications from research teams interested in studying the effectiveness of humanitarian assistance in eastern Congo. HPF and 3ie matched qualified research teams with humanitarian organizations that had previously expressed interest in the methods promoted by 3ie. Our research team was matched with the Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program, jointly managed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) and OCHA. The program that evolved into RRMP began in 2004. Currently, RRMP8 (May 2017 – April 2018) provides humanitarian assistance to groups of 500 or more households in North Kivu, South Kivu, Ituri, ex-Katanga and Tanganyika who have fled from armed conflict or natural disasters, or have recently returned to their home communities after such displacement. The program also responds to epidemics such as cholera. The RRMP8 budget is approximately 21 million USD. RRMP is a complex program that provides assistance with non-food items, health, water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), and education. To reach a consensus on a feasible and relevant study design, representatives from HPF, UNICEF, OCHA, the NGOs that implement RRMP, and the research team met a number of times over three years. The final design focuses on the largest component of RRMP: vouchers for non-food items. Thus, this study aims to generate high quality evidence to answer the following research question: What is the effect of humanitarian assistance (specifically the provision of vouchers for non-food items (NFI)) provided to recently displaced or returned persons, and vulnerable host families, on health and well-being?

q16.value: We focus on four families of primary outcomes: 1) physical health, 2) mental health, 3) social cohesion, and 4) resilience. For each family, we construct a summary index. We also test for spillovers and heterogeneous effects along several dimensions (details below). H1: NFI vouchers have a positive effect on physical health of children Measures [All the following concern children under 5 years old only]: -Mothers’ reports of diarrhea, cough, and fever among children in the last two weeks -Anthropometry: (height, weight, and MUAC) -Hemoglobin (anemia indicator) -Malaria rapid diagnostic test (RDT) H2: NFI vouchers have positive effects on mental health of adults Measures: -Selections from the Hopkins Symptom Checklist (HSC-25) -World Health Organization Well-being Index (WHO-5) H3: NFI vouchers have a positive or negative effect on social cohesion of adults Measures: -Group membership -Contributions to the village -Contributions to other households in dwelling -Problems with other households in dwelling -Trust -Incidences of theft H4: NFI vouchers have positive effect on resilience Measures: -Self-reported and enumerator observations of number of assets owned -Debt -Savings -Income -Responses to standard food security questions -Proportion of children aged 5-18 in school per household -Unhealthy behaviors (alcohol , cigarettes, etc.) We test for within-dwelling spillover effects on the same four families of outcomes, using a more limited set of indicators. (A dwelling is a structure containing one or more households) We test for heterogeneous effects along the following dimensions (two-sided tests): Baseline poverty/vulnerability Migrant/host status Ethnic majority/minority status (relative to village) Discordant or concordant ethnicities within the dwelling Assigned voucher amount per capita Occupation of recipient Education of recipient Distance to market

q17.value: We randomly assign households to receive a voucher for non-food items or control. We interview households 1-4 days before a fair where they can use their vouchers. We interview the same households again six weeks after the fair. If a household is living in a multi-household dwelling, we also randomly select an additional household in the dwelling to interview at both points in time. We estimate treatment effects using ANCOVA models.

q24.value: Catholic University of Bukavu (UCB/CIE/NC/006/2017); New York University – Abu Dhabi (#064-2017)

q27.value: Unicef via implementing NGOs: MercyCorps, Danish Refugee Council, Norwegian Refugee Council, Solidarites

attributes.title: How to measure citizens’ compliance with COVID-19 public health measures? Evidence from three survey experiments
attributes.description: The extent to which citizens comply or not with public health measures designed to limit the spread of COVID-19 strongly affects the propagation of the virus as well as the number of hospitalizations and death from the disease. It is however very difficult to identify (and then target) non-compliers because claiming to follow the rules is socially desirable. Drawing on data from three survey experiments, we examine the efficacy of “face-saving” treatments as a means of reducing social desirability and enhancing measurement of compliance. These treatments should make it more acceptable and guilty-free for citizens to admit non-compliance. We thus expect to find the proportion of non-compliance to be systematically higher in the group received the face-saving question. Considering the present context and the importance of accurately measuring and then targeting non-compliance, we argue that scholars around the world should adopt the face-saving question.

question.value:
We embed a classic “split-ballot” experimental design in three surveys administered online.

We manipulate two things:
1.	The presence or absence of a preamble that softens the compliance norm.
2.	The presence or absence of face-saving response items.

In Study 1, only the preamble is manipulated. Subjects in the treatment group receive the following preamble:

 “Some people have altered their behaviour since the beginning of the pandemic, while others have continued to pursue various activities. Some may also want to change their behaviour but cannot do so for different reasons.”

Next, all subjects receive the identical question and response options. The question reads:

“Have you done any of the following activates in the last week”?

Response options are identical in this experiment (Yes/No/Unsure).
Thus, only the preamble is manipulated.

In Study 2, everyone received the same preamble that was manipulated in Study 1. Study 2 differs in that the experiment manipulates the presence (treatment group) or absence (control group) of a face-saving response. In the control group, response options are limited to “yes,” “no,” and “not sure” responses. In the treated group, we offer “As seldom as possible” as a face-saving response.

Study 3 is identical to Study 2 except that the face-saving response option is “Only when it is necessary/occasionally”

Data for experiment 1 and 2 is collected by VoxPop Lab. Respondents were drawn from their web panel of 650,000 Canadians. Both samples are part of a 24-wave rolling study (about 2,250 respondents in each wave). All 24 waves were drawn simultaneously from the web panel on March 16, with the probability of inclusion in the sample being proportional to marginal distributions from the Canadian census. The data for Study 1 was collected between 3 April and 7 April 2020 and the data for Study 2 will be collected between 17 April and 21 April 2020 as part of the sixth wave in the aforementioned panel study

Study 3 will be administered on-line to a representative, Census-balanced sample drawn from the Leger 360 platform. This platform is a web-based panel of over 400,000 Canadian respondents, 60 percent of which were recruited randomly via Random-Digit-Dialing (RDD). The data are to be collected between April 15 to 21 as part of the first wave in a panel study led by Richard Nadeau (Université de Montréal).

-Any answer other than "no" will be taken as an indicator of non-compliance.

attributes.title: Cognitive Benefits of Exercise Intervention:  An fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: The first neuroimaging meta-analysis on cognitive benefits of exercise intervention through activation likelihood estimation (ALE).

q1.value: Qian YU, Fabian Herold, Benjamin Becker, Benjamin Klugah-Brown, Yanjie Zhang, Stephane Perrey, Nicola Veronese, Notger G. Müller, Liye Zou

q2.value:
(1) Activated clusters will not only be observed  in commonly recognized cerebrum, but also cerebellum and brainstem. 
(2) There will be neuroimaging differences between exercise interventions and other interventions.
(3) The type, duration, intensity of exercise intervention and age group will influence cognitive effects and induce activations in different brain regions.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines. 

The literature search will be conducted from an inception to April 2020, through four electronic databases (Pubmed, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and Embase). Search terms in title and abstract will be combined as follow:[movement OR “sport” OR “physical education” OR “physical activity” OR “aerobic exercise” OR “aerobic training” OR “interval training” OR “walking” OR “stretching*”   OR “coordinative exercise” OR “coordinative training” OR “plyometric exercise” OR “plyometric training” OR “resistance exercise” OR “resistance training” OR “strength exercise” OR “strength training” OR “cardiopulmonary intervention” OR “cardiorespiratory training” OR “fitness training” OR “motor skill training” run OR cycle OR dance OR TaiChi OR Yoga OR treadmill OR agility OR endurance OR “musculoskeletal intervention” OR “functional training” OR “physical therapy” OR “physiotherapy” OR exergam* OR “active gam*” OR “active play*” OR “interactive video” OR “virtual reality*” OR “motion gam*” OR Kinect OR wii*] AND [“cognition” OR “cognitive” OR “neuropsychological function” OR “executive function” OR “executive control” OR “central executive” OR “inhibitory control” OR “working memory” OR “task-switching” OR “planning” OR “attention” OR “information processing” OR “processing speed” OR “memory” OR “free recall” OR mental OR “emotion regulation” OR “cognitive regulation” OR “stress regulation” OR “psychological” OR “affective” brain OR “functional plasticity” OR “response time” OR “reaction time” OR accuracy OR error OR inhibition OR visual OR spatial OR visuospatial OR language OR oddball OR “problem solving” OR Flanker OR Stroop OR Sternberg] AND [fMRI OR MRI OR “MR imaging” OR “magnetic resonance imaging” OR “functional MRI” OR “functional magnetic resonance imaging” OR “PET” OR “positron emission tomography”OR “SPECT” OR “single-photon emission computed tomography”]. Furthermore, reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for relevant articles that are not captured through the database searches. 

Studies will only be included if they meet the following inclusion criteria: (1) peer-review journal article published in English; (2) pre-to-post experimental design with at least one group that was arranged to attend an exercise program; (3) evaluation of task-related brain activity via fMRI, PET or SPECT at baseline and post-intervention; (4) functional imaging task associated with cognition; (5) retrievable data on standard Talairach or Montreal Neurologic Institute (MNI) coordinates of whole-brain analyses, allowing for comparison of findings across studies and across laboratories. Two independent researchers (QY and LZ) will first screen article titles and abstracts, followed by full-text review against the above-mentioned inclusion criteria.  

Data will be independently extracted by two reviewers (QY and LZ), including imaging mode, population (health status) and age, intervention of experimental group (exercise type and the number of participants), intervention duration, task/stimuli, control type, and the number of Foci. A risk of bias will be assessed using the tools of PEDRO scale (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/ 10086815).

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: This is a neuroimaging meta analysis and the literature search will be conducted from an inception to April 2020, through four electronic databases (Pubmed, Web of Science, PsychInfo, and Embase). Furthermore, reference lists of included articles will be manually searched for relevant articles that are not captured through the database searches. Two independent researchers (QY and LZ) will first screen article titles and abstracts, followed by full-text review against the above-mentioned inclusion criteria.  In this study, we will perform ALE analyses with GingerALE v3.0.2.

question.value: Studies will only be included if they meet the following inclusion criteria: (1) peer-review journal article published in English; (2) pre-to-post experimental design with at least one group that was arranged to attend an exercise program; (3) evaluation of task-related brain activity via fMRI, PET or SPECT at baseline and post-intervention; (4) functional imaging task associated with cognition; (5) retrievable data on standard Talairach or Montreal Neurologic Institute (MNI) coordinates of whole-brain analyses, allowing for comparison of findings across studies and across laboratories. Two independent researchers (QY and LZ) will first screen article titles and abstracts, followed by full-text review against the above-mentioned inclusion criteria.

q11.value: There will be at least 17 studies included in this meta analysis.

q12.value: The sample size (17 studies for neuroimaging ALE meta analysis) is recommended by the owner of Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE).

q13.value: If there is no activated cluster reported or not enough experiments included, meta analysis may stop.

question.value: Retrievable data on standard Talairach or Montreal Neurologic Institute (MNI) coordinates of whole-brain analyses

In this study, we will perform Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE)  analyses with GingerALE v3.0.2 in MNI space, and cluster-based family-wise error (FEW) will be used in which a threshold of p < 0.05 will be permuted 1000 times (Eickhoff et al., 2009). Coordinates reported in the Talairach in the original studies will be transformed to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space using the Lancaster transform icbm2tal software procedure included in the Convert Foci tool of GingerALE (Laird et al., 2010). The ALE maps will be imported into Mango Version 4.1 software and overlaid on an anatomical template in MNI space for representation and comparison.

ALE is a coordinate-based meta-analytical method that has been used to determine the consistent locations of brain activation in included studies that use similar experimental conditions or tasks. In ALE, activation foci are regarded as probability distributions centered on the reported coordinates. ALE maps are constructed after calculating each space voxel’s likelihood to be activated. The null-distributions acquired from independent studies’ ALE values is usually used to test the reliability of ALE map and this process have similarities with permutation test across experiments. The contribution of each study is weighted by its sample size, and each study is considered as a random effect. The observed values in the ALE distribution are compared to the null distribution in order to assign probability estimates to the observed experimental data.

attributes.title: Effects of habitat complexity on the predictability in escape behavior of grasshoppers
attributes.description: The aim of this project is to uncover the consequences of habitat complexity and camouflage for the development of predictability during ontogeny (with the prediction that complex habitats favour unpredictability) and the immediate phenotypic flexibility in response to habitat complexity. We will work with different colour morphs that differ in the degree of crypsis.

q1.value: Effects of habitat complexity on the predictability in escape behavior of grasshoppers

q3.value: Throughout life, animals are faced with innumerable challenges and individuals differ from each other in how they respond to them. This results in alternative individual behavioral strategies that can coexist within populations. In some behavioral contexts, such as escape from predators, these strategies can be particularly diverse. Predictability (or unpredictability) in the timing and performance of flight behavior in prey species is still a poorly-explored component of escape strategies. The predictability-unpredictability axis of behavior represents a dimension of animal personality that, due to methodological constraints, has only recently gained some of the attention that it deserves. Escape behavior is particularly interesting with respect to predictability, because it offers scope for behavioral trade-offs between predictability and efficiency measured as distance. The extreme cases can be classified as maximally unpredictable (the ‘hare strategy’) or as maximally distance efficient when fleeing in a straight, long-distance path (the ‘gazelle strategy’). The hare strategy seems particularly advantageous in rich, complex habitats where unpredictable individuals can hope to find cover for hiding, while the gazelle strategy seems more efficient in unstructured habitats. For the same reason, unpredictability in behavior will be more efficient when individuals are well camouflaged. The aim of this project is to uncover the consequences of habitat complexity and camouflage for the development of predictability during ontogeny, with the prediction that complex habitats favor unpredictability in escape behavior.

q4.value: Complex habitats favor unpredictability in escape behavior.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: It is impossible to be blind to the treatment when doing regular maintenance work (feeding in particular). However, at the critical point of phenotyping, researchers were blind to the treatment. Furthermore, at the stage of scoring escape behavior from video takes, the person analyzing the video was blind to the treatment. All labels were uninformative of the treatment.

question.value: We have a randomized block design, randomly assigning (approximately) half of the individuals hatched from different egg pods of same parents to either a complex habitat treatment or a control treatment.

q9.value: The treatments (habitat complexity) were randomly assigned within families. Uneven numbers of offspring per family were randomly assigned to either treatment level. The order of phenotyping within days was randomly assigned to individuals independent of their treatment.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Treatment and phenotyping have been performed. Video analysis is in progress. Effective sample sizes are thus known. However, none of the treatment information has yet been linked to phenotypes.

question.value: Individuals of the steppe grasshopper Chorthippus dorsatus were field-caught near Jena and used to set up a lab-based half-sib breeding design with 52 males mated to five females each. Offspring were processed in 7 cohorts. In each cohort, hatchlings from different egg pods are randomly assigned to standard plain white housing cages (control treatment) or to cages with checkered pattern background (green and brown) and places to hide and climb (complex habitat treatment). Five to ten days after the final molt, animals were kept overnight at 10°C in refrigerators. They were then color marked and allowed to heat under a heat lamp for 1h before brought to the experimental room. After 5 minutes of acclimatization in an empty arena, grasshoppers were chased and their escape behavior was recorded by a camera placed above them. Each individual was chased 10 times with a 2-minute interval between trials. Videos will be processed with the software Ethovision to measure flight initiation distance, jump distance and jump angle.

q13.value: The target sample size was 1000 individuals. Up to three grasshoppers from each egg pod were phenotyped (less if less were available). Since some of the pairs did not produce eggs that hatched offspring, the final number of full-sib families (unique females) was 136 and the number of half-sib families (unique males) was 46. 919 offspring from the half-sib mating design were phenotyped.

q14.value: We aimed to reach an as high sample size as possible since we expect effect sizes to be small. Phenotyping was spread over seven cohorts in order to reach larger sample sizes. No larger sample size would have been possible to process. Hatching success constrained the ability to reach a fully balanced design with respect to families.

q15.value: The sample size was fully determined by the ability for sufficient throughput in phenotyping and the aim to equalize sample sizes between families as far as possible. All video recordings were taken before videos were analyzed for phenotype scoring. All data will be extracted before the data will be analyzed. We will analyze all available data (after quality filtering for cases of unreliable phenotypes).

question.value: We have manipulated habitat complexity during development in individual home cages. Complex habitat treatment had a green-brown checkered pattern as a background, egg cartons with holes that can be used to hide and a piece of pipe cleaner added as an extra climbing option next to the grass leaves and cage walls. The control group had a simple (plain white) cage, containing only the grass pot and a tube of water.

Dependent variables: individual mean and individual variance (predictability) in flight initiation distance (FID) defined as the minimum distance from the chaser before the grasshopper initiate escape behavior), jump distance and jump angle (measured relative to the direction of approach).
Independent variable: habitat complexity treatment (complex or control).
Variable with potential interaction with the treatment: color morph (uniform green, uniform brown, dorsal-striped brown, lateral green, dorsal green) ordered by plainness and greenness (0=uniform brown, 1=dorsal-striped brown, 2= uniform green, 3= dorsal green, 4= lateral green).
Confounding variables: sex, age, daytime and temperature during the experiment.
Nuisance variables: cohort, development time (days between hatching and final molt) and body weight.
Random effects of interest: Pedigree.
Random effects (nuisance): Phenotyping date.

We will use double hierarchical models that model behavior (FID, jump distance and jump angle in separate models) as a function of fixed and random effects and a part of the model that models residual variance as a function of fixed effects (and, if possible, random effects).
Model: response ~ habitat complexity * color morph + sex + age + age^2 + daytime + daytime^2 + temperature + (1 I Individual ID) + (1 I Pedigree) + (1 I Phenotyping Date) + error
error ~ habitat complexity * color morph + sex + (1 I Individual ID)+ (1 I Pedigree)+ (1 I Phenotyping Date)
In case of convergence problems, we will first drop the terms age, age^2, daytime and datytime^2. In case of further convergence problems, we will drop color morph (first the interaction, then the main effect). The effect of the color morph will be fitted as a continuous variable as shown above (in order to keep the model as simple as possible), but the option to fit color morph as a factor will also be explored.

q20.value: FID and Jump distance will be transformed with log(x+1).

q22.value: Individuals with severe deformations, lost legs or otherwise unhealthy will be removed.

q23.value: We have to assume that data are missing at random, since data augmentation is, to our knowledge, not available for double hierarchical models.

q24.value: We will explore the effect of color morph fitted as a five-level categorical predictor.

registration_responses.q1: Effects of habitat complexity on the predictability in escape behavior of grasshoppers
registration_responses.q3: Throughout life, animals are faced with innumerable challenges and individuals differ from each other in how they respond to them. This results in alternative individual behavioral strategies that can coexist within populations. In some behavioral contexts, such as escape from predators, these strategies can be particularly diverse. Predictability (or unpredictability) in the timing and performance of flight behavior in prey species is still a poorly-explored component of escape strategies. The predictability-unpredictability axis of behavior represents a dimension of animal personality that, due to methodological constraints, has only recently gained some of the attention that it deserves. Escape behavior is particularly interesting with respect to predictability, because it offers scope for behavioral trade-offs between predictability and efficiency measured as distance. The extreme cases can be classified as maximally unpredictable (the ‘hare strategy’) or as maximally distance efficient when fleeing in a straight, long-distance path (the ‘gazelle strategy’). The hare strategy seems particularly advantageous in rich, complex habitats where unpredictable individuals can hope to find cover for hiding, while the gazelle strategy seems more efficient in unstructured habitats. For the same reason, unpredictability in behavior will be more efficient when individuals are well camouflaged. The aim of this project is to uncover the consequences of habitat complexity and camouflage for the development of predictability during ontogeny, with the prediction that complex habitats favor unpredictability in escape behavior.
registration_responses.q4: Complex habitats favor unpredictability in escape behavior.

attributes.title: Seeking to Understand the Cognitive Processing of Sexual Cues in Asexual Individuals and Heterosexual Women with Desire/Arousal Difficulties

q1.value: Seeking to Understand the Cognitive Processing of Sexual Cues in Asexual Individuals and Heterosexual Women with Desire/Arousal Difficulties

q2.value: Natalie Brown, Doug Vanderlaan, Alan Kingstone, Bozena Zdaniuk, Diana Peragine, Lori Brotto

q3.value: Asexuality is defined as a lack of sexual attraction to others, with data supporting its conceptualization as a sexual orientation. However, some clinicians challenge this viewpoint, positing that asexual people suffer from a sexual desire disorder. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD) is characterized by absent/reduced sexual interest/arousal paired with personal distress. There are two SIAD subtypes: acquired and lifelong. Research suggests that while asexuality and acquired SIAD are distinct entities, there may be some overlap between asexuality and lifelong SIAD. Findings from studies of visual attention to and appraisals of sexual cues suggest that unique neural mechanisms underlie asexuality and SIAD. However, no study has directly compared these groups' cognitive processing of sexual cues. Further, many studies examining SIAD exclude women with the lifelong subtype, resulting in a lack of knowledge about their experiences. This study aims to improve our understanding of the differences between asexuality and SIAD through an examination of these groups' cognitive processing of sexual cues. Asexual individuals and women with lifelong or acquired SIAD will complete a visual attention task, a sex-related implicit association task (SC-IAT), and a self-report measure of explicit attitudes towards sex. This project will shed light on key differences between asexuality and SIAD, and is the first study to separate acquired and lifelong SIAD.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Visual attention: Asexual individuals will not display an attentional bias for erotic cues, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will exhibit a sex-specific bias. 
a) Asexual individuals will  have no differences in number or total duration of fixations to sexual and non-sexual images, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will make more fixations and have longer total gaze durations to sexual relative to non-sexual images. Further, asexual individuals will spend an equivalent proportion of time in each trial attending to the sexual and non-sexual images, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will spend a greater proportion of time per trial attending to the sexual compared to the non-sexual images. We hypothesize no differences in gaze behaviour for women with different SIAD subtypes. 
b) Women with acquired and lifelong SIAD will spend a greater proportion of time in per trial attending to regions of sexual contact within the sexual images (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, and fellatio) relative to the asexual individuals. We hypothesize no differences in gaze behaviour for women with different SIAD subtypes. 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit appraisals: Asexual individuals and women with lifelong SIAD will display less positive implicit appraisals of sexual stimuli compared to women with acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower SC-IAT D-scores. We predict no differences in asexual individuals' and women with lifelong SIAD's implicit appraisals of erotic cues. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals: Asexual individuals will report less positive explicit appraisals of sex relative to women with lifelong and acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower scores on the Sex Semantic Differential Scale (SSDS; Bulmer & Izuma, 2018) relative to the latter groups. We predict no differences in explicit appraisals of sex between women with different SIAD subtypes.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Hypothesis 1: Visual attention (Primary Endpoint) 
a) Mixed design with 1 between subjects factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD) and 1 within-subjects factor (image type) with 2 levels (sexual image, non-sexual image).   
b) Between subjects design with 1 factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, and heterosexual with lifelong SIAD). 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
Between subjects design with 1 factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, and heterosexual with lifelong SIAD). 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
Between subjects design with 1 factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, and heterosexual with lifelong SIAD).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Natalie Brown, the study coordinator, is the only person who has had access to the data for the purpose of checking for missing data so that recruitment targets could be modified accordingly. No data analysis has been conducted.

question.value: Participants are being recruited in the Vancouver and Toronto communities via advertisements posted on the Asexuality Visibility and Education Network (AVEN), the UBC Sexual Health Research website, and social media. Tear-off ads have been posted around the University of British Columbia and University of Toronto campuses, and in nearby locations such as community centres, related therapy clinics, grocery stores, and cafés. The recruitment ad was also distributed through the Vancouver Coastal Health email broadcast. Participants are paid $25 for their time. Participants  must be at least 19 years of age, fluent in English, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, and identify as either asexual or heterosexual. Individuals who are interested in study participation contact the study coordinator (Natalie Brown) via email and she conducts a phone screen with them to assess study eligibility. Data collection began in March 2019 and will be end in June 2020 due to time constraints (i.e., the study coordinator needs to defend this project as her Master's thesis).

q13.value: Our target sample is 66 participants (22 asexual individuals, 22 heterosexual women with lifelong SIAD, 22 heterosexual women with acquired SIAD). We will attempt to recruit up to 75, accounting for ~10% data loss due to experimenter error.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a large effect size f = 0.40 at the standard 0.5 alpha error probability for Hypotheses 2 (implicit appraisals) and 3 (explicit appraisals). Additional a priori power analyses revealed that a smaller sample size would be needed to detect hypothesized group differences in visual attention (f = 0.25) for Hypothesis 1.

question.value: n/a

Grouping Variables 
1. Sexual orientation: Participants were asked to self-report their sexual orientation from a list of options including heterosexual, bisexual, demisexual, heterosexual, gay/lesbian, and pansexual. Sexual orientation was also assessed using the Kinsey Sexual Attraction Scale (Kinsey et al., 1953). 
2. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD): The study coordinator assesses SIAD symptoms by conducting a phone screen with each participant, asking them to respond to questions about desire and arousal difficulties. Participants are asked whether they have experienced an absence/reduction in the following: sexual interest, sexual thoughts/fantasies, initiation of sexual activity or receptivity to sexual advances, responses to erotic cues (e.g., a sex scene in a movie), sexual excitement/pleasure, and genital/non-genital sensations. A diagnosis of SIAD is made if women endorse at least three of these six symptoms for a duration of 6 months or longer, and report that these symptoms are causing significant personal distress. 

Outcome Measures (Dependent Variables)
Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint)
We will measure three dependent variables of interest: (1) Total fixation count (TFC) is the total number of fixations in an area of interest (AOI); (2) Total fixation duration (TFD) is the total amount of time spent (in seconds) in an AOI across the total stimulus presentation time; (3) Proportion of time (PT) is the percentage of the total stimulus presentation time spent in a particular AOI. For each trial, TFC, TFD, and PT will be calculated for each sexual and non-sexual image, In addition, PT will be calculated for the region of sexual contact (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, fellatio) within each sexual image.  These scores will be averaged across 20 experimental trials to result in mean controlled attention scores for each target type (i.e., sexual image, non-sexual image, region of sexual contact within the sexual image). 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint)
SC-IAT effects will be operationalized by D-scores, which range from -2, indicative of a negative implicit bias towards sexual cues,  to +2, indicative of a positive implicit bias. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint)
We will use a self-report measure of attitudes towards sex developed by Bulmer & Izuma (2018). We refer to this scale as the Sex Semantic Differential Scale; please find it attached to this registration application. 

Predictors/Covariates
1. Asexual identity: Assessed using the Asexuality Identification Scale (AIS; Yule, Brotto, & Gorzalka, 2015). Respondents use a Likert scale to rate the applicability of various statements (e.g., I would be content if I never had sex again) to their experience, with responses ranging from 1 (completely false) to 5 (completely true). 
2. Sexual Interest/Desire: Assessed using the Sexual Desire Inventory-2 (SDI-2; Spector, Carey, & Steinberg, 1996). Participants are presented with 14 statements and use 8- and 9-point Likert scales to rate the frequency and intensity of their feelings of desire, as well as the importance of engaging in partnered and non-partnered sexual activities. 
3. Sexual Distress: Assessed by the Female Sexual Distress Scale-Revised (FSDS-R; Derogatis, Clayton, Lewis-D'Agostino, Wunderlich, & Fu, 2008). Respondents rate 12 statements using a Likert  scale ranging from 0 (never) to 4 (always) to indicate how often they experienced distress related to sexual problems. 
4. Depressive Symptoms: Assessed by the second edition of the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II; Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) and the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977). The BDI-II consists of 21 statements that participants rate on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 to 3, with scores greater than 15 typically being used to identify individuals likely to meet diagnostic criteria for depression. The CES-D includes 20 statements (e.g., I was bothered by things that don't usually bother me), and participants indicate how often they felt or behaved a certain way in the past week using a Likert scale ranging from 0 (rarely or none of the time - less than 1 day) to 3 (most or all of the time - 5-7 days). 
5. Genital Self-Image: Assessed by the Female Genital Self-Image Scale (FGSIS; Herbenick & Reece, 2010). Respondents rate seven statements about their genitals using a 4-point response scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). 
6. Sexual Aversion: Assessed by the Sexual Aversion Scale (Katz, Gipson, Kearl, & Krikovitch, 1989). Respondents rated the applicability of 30 statements (e.g., I worry a lot about sex) to their experience using a Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all like me) to 4 (a lot like me). 
7. Genital pain: Women will be assessed during a phone screen for symptoms of Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder (GPPPD), and will be asked whether they have experienced difficulties with vaginal penetration, pain in their genitals or lower abdomen, pain-related anxiety, or unwanted tensing/tightening of the pelvic floor muscles. A diagnosis of GPPPD will be given if they endorse any of these criteria for a duration of 6 months or longer, and if they report that these symptoms cause personally significant distress.  
8. Site: Given that asexual individuals make up approximately 0.4-1% of the general population (Aicken, Mercer, & Cassell, 2013; Bogaert, 2004, 2013), we recruited from two different Canadian cities (i.e., Vancouver, Toronto) in order to meet our target sample size.

Grouping Variables 
1. Sexual orientation: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead, the number of participants that select each sexual identity will be displayed in the results section of the manuscript, along with other demographic variables. 
2. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD): No indices will be calculated for this variable. Participants who identify as heterosexual and meet diagnostic criteria for either lifelong or acquired SIAD will be assigned to the appropriate groups. 

Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Outcome Measure)
For each trial, TFC, TFD, and PT will be calculated for each sexual and non-sexual image, In addition, PT will be calculated for the region of sexual contact (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, fellatio) within each sexual image.  These scores will be averaged across 20 experimental trials to result in mean TFC, TFD, and PT scores for two AOIs  (i.e., sexual image, non-sexual image) with a PT score only for the AOI containing the area of sexual contact. 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Outcome Measure)
D-scores for each participant will be calculated by the INQUISIT software program using the standard IAT scoring algorithm (Greenwald, Nosek, & Banjali, 2003). 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Outcome Measure) 
Participants’ ratings on the 11 questions of the Sex Semantic Differential Scale (SSDS) will be averaged to yield a mean score for each subject. 

Predictors/Covariates
1. Asexual identity: Total AIS scores (12-60) will be calculated by summing individual responses, with higher scores indicating a greater likelihood that the participant identifies as asexual.
2: Sexual Interest/Desire: Dyadic and solitary subscale scores will be calculated by summing individual items, with the former ranging from 0 to 70 and the latter from 0 to 31.  Higher scores indicate greater desire. Item 14 will not be included in these calculations, as it does not load onto either factor (Spector et al., 1996).
3: Sexual Distress: Total scores ranging from 0 to 48 will be calculated by summing individual items. Higher scores are indicative of greater sex-related distress, and scores >11 have been recommended to distinguish individuals with clinically low desire from age-matched controls (Derogatis et al., 2007). 
4: Depressive symptoms: Total scores for the BDI-II will be calculated by summing individual items, ranging from 0-84, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms.  CES-D info must be included. 
5: Genital Self-Image: A total FGSIS score (7-28) will calculated by summing all individual item scores. Higher scores indicated more positive genital self-image.
6: Sexual Aversion: Total scores and scale means will be calculated. Higher scores are indicative of greater sexual aversion. 
7: Genital pain: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead,  participants who identify as heterosexual will be assigned a value of 1 if they meet diagnostic criteria for GPPPD, or 0 if they do not meet diagnostic criteria (i.e., 1 = GPPPD present, 0 = GPPPD absent). 
8. Site: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead, participants recruited in Vancouver will be assigned a value of 1, whereas participants recruited in Toronto will be assigned a value of 2.

Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint) 
To test our first hypothesis that asexual individuals will non-preferentially view sexual and non-sexual stimuli, whereas women with lifelong or acquired SIAD will display a controlled attention bias to sexual images, three separate 2(Stimulus Type: erotic, non-erotic) x 3(Group: asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) repeated measures Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) will be conducted using TFC, TFD, and PT scores as dependent variables. Interactions will be followed up using Toothaker’s t-tests (Toothaker, 1991). Additionally, to examine differences in attention to the region of sexual contact within sexual images we will conduct a one-way ANOVA using Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and PT to this area of interest as the dependent variable. The main effect will be followed up by independent samples t-tests.

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
To test our second hypothesis that asexual individuals and women with lifelong SIAD will exhibit less positive implicit appraisals of sexual stimuli than women with acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower D-scores relative to women with acquired sexual desire concerns, we will conduct a one-way ANOVA using Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and SC-IAT effect (i.e., D-score) as the dependent variable. The main effect will be followed up by independent samples t-tests.

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
To test our third hypothesis that asexual individuals will display less positive explicit appraisals of sex than women with lifelong or acquired SIAD, we will conduct a one-way ANOVA with Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and mean SSDS scores as the dependent variable. 

Potential covariates will be explored.

q20.value:
Coding Scheme for Categorical Variables 
Sexual Orientation: 1 = asexual; 2 = bisexual; 3 = demisexual; 4 = heterosexual; 5 = gay/lesbian, 6 = pansexual. 
Genital pain: 1 = GPPPD present; 2 = GPPPD absent 
Site: 1 = Vancouver; 2 = Toronto

q21.value: Given recent recommendations to shift away from reliance on null hypothesis significance testing and p<.05 as a tool to determine the validity of scientific conclusions (reviewed by Wasserstein, Schirm, & Lazar, 2019), when reporting the results of all our analyses we will prioritize effect sizes and confidence intervals. Additionally, we will not use the terms “statistically significant” or “not statistically significant”. However, we will include p-values and inferential tests in our results for the readers’ consideration. We will use two-tailed tests for all analyses.

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis. We will only exclude data that we believe to be invalid.

q23.value:
Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint) 
If a participant has more than 20% data loss (i.e., they did not attend to 4 or more of the 20 experimental trials, closing their eyes or looking away from the screen), then their data will be excluded from analyses of this endpoint.  

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
Given that participants must answer all questions in order to complete the sex SC-IAT and proceed with the remainder of the experiment, which all of our participants have done thus far, we foresee no need to deal with incomplete or missing data for this measure. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
We will use mean replacement for up to 20% of missing data.

q25.value:
References

Bogaert, A. F. (2004). Asexuality: Prevalence and associated factors in a national probability sample. Journal of Sex Research, 41, 279.

Bogaert, A. F. (2013). Demography of asexuality. In A.K. Baumle (Ed.), International handbook on the demography of sexuality, international handbooks of population (Vol. 5, pp. 275288). Dordrecht: Springer.

Bulmer, M., & Izuma, K. (2018). Implicit and explicit attitudes towards sex and romance in asexuals. The Journal of Sex Research, 55, 962-974.

Demicheli, F. B., Cojan, Y., & Waber, L. (2011). Neural bases of hypoactive sexual desire disorder in women: An event-related fMRI study. Journal of Sexual Medicine; 8, 25462559.

DeRogatis, L., Clayton, A., Lewis-D’Agostino, D., Wunderlich, G., & Fu, Y. (2008). Validation of the Female Sexual Distress Scale-Revised for assessing distress in women with Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder. Journal of Sexual Medicine, 5, 357-364.

Greenwald, A.G., Nosek, B.A., & Banjali, M.R. (2003). Understanding and using the Implicit Association Test: I. An improved scoring algorithm. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 85, 197-216.

registration_responses.q1: Seeking to Understand the Cognitive Processing of Sexual Cues in Asexual Individuals and Heterosexual Women with Desire/Arousal Difficulties
registration_responses.q2: Natalie Brown, Doug Vanderlaan, Alan Kingstone, Bozena Zdaniuk, Diana Peragine, Lori Brotto
registration_responses.q3: Asexuality is defined as a lack of sexual attraction to others, with data supporting its conceptualization as a sexual orientation. However, some clinicians challenge this viewpoint, positing that asexual people suffer from a sexual desire disorder. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD) is characterized by absent/reduced sexual interest/arousal paired with personal distress. There are two SIAD subtypes: acquired and lifelong. Research suggests that while asexuality and acquired SIAD are distinct entities, there may be some overlap between asexuality and lifelong SIAD. Findings from studies of visual attention to and appraisals of sexual cues suggest that unique neural mechanisms underlie asexuality and SIAD. However, no study has directly compared these groups' cognitive processing of sexual cues. Further, many studies examining SIAD exclude women with the lifelong subtype, resulting in a lack of knowledge about their experiences. This study aims to improve our understanding of the differences between asexuality and SIAD through an examination of these groups' cognitive processing of sexual cues. Asexual individuals and women with lifelong or acquired SIAD will complete a visual attention task, a sex-related implicit association task (SC-IAT), and a self-report measure of explicit attitudes towards sex. This project will shed light on key differences between asexuality and SIAD, and is the first study to separate acquired and lifelong SIAD.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis 1: Visual attention: Asexual individuals will not display an attentional bias for erotic cues, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will exhibit a sex-specific bias. 
a) Asexual individuals will  have no differences in number or total duration of fixations to sexual and non-sexual images, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will make more fixations and have longer total gaze durations to sexual relative to non-sexual images. Further, asexual individuals will spend an equivalent proportion of time in each trial attending to the sexual and non-sexual images, whereas women with lifelong and acquired SIAD will spend a greater proportion of time per trial attending to the sexual compared to the non-sexual images. We hypothesize no differences in gaze behaviour for women with different SIAD subtypes. 
b) Women with acquired and lifelong SIAD will spend a greater proportion of time in per trial attending to regions of sexual contact within the sexual images (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, and fellatio) relative to the asexual individuals. We hypothesize no differences in gaze behaviour for women with different SIAD subtypes. 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit appraisals: Asexual individuals and women with lifelong SIAD will display less positive implicit appraisals of sexual stimuli compared to women with acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower SC-IAT D-scores. We predict no differences in asexual individuals' and women with lifelong SIAD's implicit appraisals of erotic cues. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals: Asexual individuals will report less positive explicit appraisals of sex relative to women with lifelong and acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower scores on the Sex Semantic Differential Scale (SSDS; Bulmer & Izuma, 2018) relative to the latter groups. We predict no differences in explicit appraisals of sex between women with different SIAD subtypes.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Natalie Brown, the study coordinator, is the only person who has had access to the data for the purpose of checking for missing data so that recruitment targets could be modified accordingly. No data analysis has been conducted.
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample is 66 participants (22 asexual individuals, 22 heterosexual women with lifelong SIAD, 22 heterosexual women with acquired SIAD). We will attempt to recruit up to 75, accounting for ~10% data loss due to experimenter error.
registration_responses.q14: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a large effect size f = 0.40 at the standard 0.5 alpha error probability for Hypotheses 2 (implicit appraisals) and 3 (explicit appraisals). Additional a priori power analyses revealed that a smaller sample size would be needed to detect hypothesized group differences in visual attention (f = 0.25) for Hypothesis 1.
registration_responses.q20:
Coding Scheme for Categorical Variables 
Sexual Orientation: 1 = asexual; 2 = bisexual; 3 = demisexual; 4 = heterosexual; 5 = gay/lesbian, 6 = pansexual. 
Genital pain: 1 = GPPPD present; 2 = GPPPD absent 
Site: 1 = Vancouver; 2 = Toronto
registration_responses.q21: Given recent recommendations to shift away from reliance on null hypothesis significance testing and p<.05 as a tool to determine the validity of scientific conclusions (reviewed by Wasserstein, Schirm, & Lazar, 2019), when reporting the results of all our analyses we will prioritize effect sizes and confidence intervals. Additionally, we will not use the terms “statistically significant” or “not statistically significant”. However, we will include p-values and inferential tests in our results for the readers’ consideration. We will use two-tailed tests for all analyses.
registration_responses.q22: Outliers will be included in the analysis. We will only exclude data that we believe to be invalid.
registration_responses.q23:
Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint) 
If a participant has more than 20% data loss (i.e., they did not attend to 4 or more of the 20 experimental trials, closing their eyes or looking away from the screen), then their data will be excluded from analyses of this endpoint.  

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
Given that participants must answer all questions in order to complete the sex SC-IAT and proceed with the remainder of the experiment, which all of our participants have done thus far, we foresee no need to deal with incomplete or missing data for this measure. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
We will use mean replacement for up to 20% of missing data.

Hypothesis 1: Visual attention (Primary Endpoint) 
a) Mixed design with 1 between subjects factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD) and 1 within-subjects factor (image type) with 2 levels (sexual image, non-sexual image).   
b) Between subjects design with 1 factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, and heterosexual with lifelong SIAD). 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
Between subjects design with 1 factor (group) with 3 levels (asexual, heterosexual with acquired SIAD, and heterosexual with lifelong SIAD). 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit appraisals (Secondary Endpoint)
