registration_responses.q12.question: Participants are being recruited in the Vancouver and Toronto communities via advertisements posted on the Asexuality Visibility and Education Network (AVEN), the UBC Sexual Health Research website, and social media. Tear-off ads have been posted around the University of British Columbia and University of Toronto campuses, and in nearby locations such as community centres, related therapy clinics, grocery stores, and cafés. The recruitment ad was also distributed through the Vancouver Coastal Health email broadcast. Participants are paid $25 for their time. Participants  must be at least 19 years of age, fluent in English, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision, and identify as either asexual or heterosexual. Individuals who are interested in study participation contact the study coordinator (Natalie Brown) via email and she conducts a phone screen with them to assess study eligibility. Data collection began in March 2019 and will be end in June 2020 due to time constraints (i.e., the study coordinator needs to defend this project as her Master's thesis).
registration_responses.q16.question: n/a
registration_responses.q17.question:
Grouping Variables 
1. Sexual orientation: Participants were asked to self-report their sexual orientation from a list of options including heterosexual, bisexual, demisexual, heterosexual, gay/lesbian, and pansexual. Sexual orientation was also assessed using the Kinsey Sexual Attraction Scale (Kinsey et al., 1953). 
2. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD): The study coordinator assesses SIAD symptoms by conducting a phone screen with each participant, asking them to respond to questions about desire and arousal difficulties. Participants are asked whether they have experienced an absence/reduction in the following: sexual interest, sexual thoughts/fantasies, initiation of sexual activity or receptivity to sexual advances, responses to erotic cues (e.g., a sex scene in a movie), sexual excitement/pleasure, and genital/non-genital sensations. A diagnosis of SIAD is made if women endorse at least three of these six symptoms for a duration of 6 months or longer, and report that these symptoms are causing significant personal distress. 

Outcome Measures (Dependent Variables)
Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint)
We will measure three dependent variables of interest: (1) Total fixation count (TFC) is the total number of fixations in an area of interest (AOI); (2) Total fixation duration (TFD) is the total amount of time spent (in seconds) in an AOI across the total stimulus presentation time; (3) Proportion of time (PT) is the percentage of the total stimulus presentation time spent in a particular AOI. For each trial, TFC, TFD, and PT will be calculated for each sexual and non-sexual image, In addition, PT will be calculated for the region of sexual contact (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, fellatio) within each sexual image.  These scores will be averaged across 20 experimental trials to result in mean controlled attention scores for each target type (i.e., sexual image, non-sexual image, region of sexual contact within the sexual image). 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint)
SC-IAT effects will be operationalized by D-scores, which range from -2, indicative of a negative implicit bias towards sexual cues,  to +2, indicative of a positive implicit bias. 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint)
We will use a self-report measure of attitudes towards sex developed by Bulmer & Izuma (2018). We refer to this scale as the Sex Semantic Differential Scale; please find it attached to this registration application. 

Predictors/Covariates
1. Asexual identity: Assessed using the Asexuality Identification Scale (AIS; Yule, Brotto, & Gorzalka, 2015). Respondents use a Likert scale to rate the applicability of various statements (e.g., I would be content if I never had sex again) to their experience, with responses ranging from 1 (completely false) to 5 (completely true). 
2. Sexual Interest/Desire: Assessed using the Sexual Desire Inventory-2 (SDI-2; Spector, Carey, & Steinberg, 1996). Participants are presented with 14 statements and use 8- and 9-point Likert scales to rate the frequency and intensity of their feelings of desire, as well as the importance of engaging in partnered and non-partnered sexual activities. 
3. Sexual Distress: Assessed by the Female Sexual Distress Scale-Revised (FSDS-R; Derogatis, Clayton, Lewis-D'Agostino, Wunderlich, & Fu, 2008). Respondents rate 12 statements using a Likert  scale ranging from 0 (never) to 4 (always) to indicate how often they experienced distress related to sexual problems. 
4. Depressive Symptoms: Assessed by the second edition of the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II; Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) and the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977). The BDI-II consists of 21 statements that participants rate on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 to 3, with scores greater than 15 typically being used to identify individuals likely to meet diagnostic criteria for depression. The CES-D includes 20 statements (e.g., I was bothered by things that don't usually bother me), and participants indicate how often they felt or behaved a certain way in the past week using a Likert scale ranging from 0 (rarely or none of the time - less than 1 day) to 3 (most or all of the time - 5-7 days). 
5. Genital Self-Image: Assessed by the Female Genital Self-Image Scale (FGSIS; Herbenick & Reece, 2010). Respondents rate seven statements about their genitals using a 4-point response scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). 
6. Sexual Aversion: Assessed by the Sexual Aversion Scale (Katz, Gipson, Kearl, & Krikovitch, 1989). Respondents rated the applicability of 30 statements (e.g., I worry a lot about sex) to their experience using a Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all like me) to 4 (a lot like me). 
7. Genital pain: Women will be assessed during a phone screen for symptoms of Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder (GPPPD), and will be asked whether they have experienced difficulties with vaginal penetration, pain in their genitals or lower abdomen, pain-related anxiety, or unwanted tensing/tightening of the pelvic floor muscles. A diagnosis of GPPPD will be given if they endorse any of these criteria for a duration of 6 months or longer, and if they report that these symptoms cause personally significant distress.  
8. Site: Given that asexual individuals make up approximately 0.4-1% of the general population (Aicken, Mercer, & Cassell, 2013; Bogaert, 2004, 2013), we recruited from two different Canadian cities (i.e., Vancouver, Toronto) in order to meet our target sample size.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Grouping Variables 
1. Sexual orientation: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead, the number of participants that select each sexual identity will be displayed in the results section of the manuscript, along with other demographic variables. 
2. Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD): No indices will be calculated for this variable. Participants who identify as heterosexual and meet diagnostic criteria for either lifelong or acquired SIAD will be assigned to the appropriate groups. 

Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Outcome Measure)
For each trial, TFC, TFD, and PT will be calculated for each sexual and non-sexual image, In addition, PT will be calculated for the region of sexual contact (i.e., penile-vaginal penetration, cunnilingus, fellatio) within each sexual image.  These scores will be averaged across 20 experimental trials to result in mean TFC, TFD, and PT scores for two AOIs  (i.e., sexual image, non-sexual image) with a PT score only for the AOI containing the area of sexual contact. 

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Outcome Measure)
D-scores for each participant will be calculated by the INQUISIT software program using the standard IAT scoring algorithm (Greenwald, Nosek, & Banjali, 2003). 

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Outcome Measure) 
Participants’ ratings on the 11 questions of the Sex Semantic Differential Scale (SSDS) will be averaged to yield a mean score for each subject. 

Predictors/Covariates
1. Asexual identity: Total AIS scores (12-60) will be calculated by summing individual responses, with higher scores indicating a greater likelihood that the participant identifies as asexual.
2: Sexual Interest/Desire: Dyadic and solitary subscale scores will be calculated by summing individual items, with the former ranging from 0 to 70 and the latter from 0 to 31.  Higher scores indicate greater desire. Item 14 will not be included in these calculations, as it does not load onto either factor (Spector et al., 1996).
3: Sexual Distress: Total scores ranging from 0 to 48 will be calculated by summing individual items. Higher scores are indicative of greater sex-related distress, and scores >11 have been recommended to distinguish individuals with clinically low desire from age-matched controls (Derogatis et al., 2007). 
4: Depressive symptoms: Total scores for the BDI-II will be calculated by summing individual items, ranging from 0-84, with higher scores indicating more severe depressive symptoms.  CES-D info must be included. 
5: Genital Self-Image: A total FGSIS score (7-28) will calculated by summing all individual item scores. Higher scores indicated more positive genital self-image.
6: Sexual Aversion: Total scores and scale means will be calculated. Higher scores are indicative of greater sexual aversion. 
7: Genital pain: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead,  participants who identify as heterosexual will be assigned a value of 1 if they meet diagnostic criteria for GPPPD, or 0 if they do not meet diagnostic criteria (i.e., 1 = GPPPD present, 0 = GPPPD absent). 
8. Site: No indices will be calculated for this variable. Instead, participants recruited in Vancouver will be assigned a value of 1, whereas participants recruited in Toronto will be assigned a value of 2.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis 1: Visual Attention (Primary Endpoint) 
To test our first hypothesis that asexual individuals will non-preferentially view sexual and non-sexual stimuli, whereas women with lifelong or acquired SIAD will display a controlled attention bias to sexual images, three separate 2(Stimulus Type: erotic, non-erotic) x 3(Group: asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) repeated measures Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) will be conducted using TFC, TFD, and PT scores as dependent variables. Interactions will be followed up using Toothaker’s t-tests (Toothaker, 1991). Additionally, to examine differences in attention to the region of sexual contact within sexual images we will conduct a one-way ANOVA using Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and PT to this area of interest as the dependent variable. The main effect will be followed up by independent samples t-tests.

Hypothesis 2: Implicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
To test our second hypothesis that asexual individuals and women with lifelong SIAD will exhibit less positive implicit appraisals of sexual stimuli than women with acquired SIAD, such that they will have lower D-scores relative to women with acquired sexual desire concerns, we will conduct a one-way ANOVA using Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and SC-IAT effect (i.e., D-score) as the dependent variable. The main effect will be followed up by independent samples t-tests.

Hypothesis 3: Explicit Appraisals (Secondary Endpoint) 
To test our third hypothesis that asexual individuals will display less positive explicit appraisals of sex than women with lifelong or acquired SIAD, we will conduct a one-way ANOVA with Group (asexual, heterosexual with lifelong SIAD, heterosexual with acquired SIAD) as the independent variable and mean SSDS scores as the dependent variable. 

Potential covariates will be explored.

attributes.title: Physical capacity in Pulmonary Hypertension
attributes.description: Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a common complication of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Reduced exercise capacity has already been observed by some studies in COPD patients with PH as opposed to COPD patients without PH. A recent study by our group (7) has observed reduced predicted peak oxygen consumption (VO2peak), reduced endurance time and lower distance in the 6-minute walking test (6MWD) in COPD patients with PH as opposed to COPD patients without PH. Nevertheless, to date, no systematic review or meta-analysis has been conducted to summarize the most relevant parameters altered during the 6MWT in patients with COPD-PH and COPD without PH. Our objective is to determine if pulmonary hypertension in patients with COPD, is a prognostic factor for lower exercise capacity.

q2.value: PH is a prognostic factor for lower exercise capacity in patients with COPD. The distance walked in 6MWT is significantly lower in patients with COPD-PH compared with the patient’s COPD without PH.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: Two review authors (RT-LV) independently and in duplicate will extract the data.  The review authors will not be blinded to the authors of the included studies.

question.value:
Systematic review
The following sources will be used: MEDLINE/Pubmed, EMBASE, Web of Science, CINAHL, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Scielo,	reference lists of included articles
The reference lists of included studies will be searched for further eligible studies.  A full copy of the protocol and search strategies will be included in the uploaded files.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Article review will be performed independently by investigators that have experience in metaanalysis and training in the literature review. The 1st step will be the revision of the titles and abstracts of all references by two investigators (RTC-LVC). Studies deemed not relevant based on the review of the title and abstract will be excluded. Any disagreements will be solved by a third reviewer (EGS). The 2nd step will be read the articles selected in the first step in the full-text version and will be checked again the eligibility criteria (RTC-LVC). Any disagreements will be solved by the third reviewer (EGS). Additional unpublished data will be obtained from study authors where possible.

Methodological quality assessment 
The risk of bias of the included studies will be assessed with the Quality in Prognosis Studies (QUIPS) risk-of-bias tool. To minimize bias, the studies will be graded independently by two reviewers (XAR-LP). Any discrepancies in the assessment will be sorted by a third reviewer (RTC).

1. Walked distance (meters or percentage of the predicted value)
2. Pulse oxygen saturation (baseline, final and nadir)
3. Heart rate (baseline, final and recovery at the first minute)
4. Dyspnea assessment
5. Legs fatigue

Data synthesis and analysis
We will report summaries of the association between the prognostic factor and the outcomes for each study in terms of mean differences. We will compare absolute values. We obtained combined measures of effect for each primary outcome through metanalysis under a random-effect model, due to the expected heterogeneity between studies in prognostic reviews. Statistical heterogeneity will be measure through the I2 statistica and will be classified as low (I2 <25%), moderate (I2 25–50%), or high (I2 >50%).

attributes.title: Gossip About COVID-19 Infection versus Recovery and Social Distancing Norm Violation versus Adherence
attributes.description: This project concerns a scenario study whereparticipants are asked to imagine a situation in which they receive gossip from a friend about an acquaintance of their friend, who they do not know. The gossip varies on two dimensions in 3x3 full-factorial design. First, the gossip describes the acquaintance as either having recovered from infection with the Coronavirus, as currently infected (symptomatic) with the Coronavirus, or provides no information on infection with the Coronavirus. Secondly, the information describes the acquaintance as either adhering to social distancing norms, as violating social distancing norms, or provides no information about social distancing norms. Participants react to the scenario by indicating their emotions, how they perceive the acquaintance, their friend, and the communicated information. In the end, participants complete individual difference measures and questionnaires about their attitudes concerning the Coronavirus as well as providing demographic information.

q2.value:
If people accurately track infection risks, we would expect people to react most negatively to targets of gossip described as posing a high risk of spreading the Coronavirus (actively infected with the coronavirus and/or violating social distancing) compared to targets of gossip described as posing a low risk of spreading the Coronavirus (having recovered from the coronavirus and/or adhering to social distancing). However, if people do not accurately track infection risk (e.g., bias against recovered targets of gossip, overestimating risks), we expect no difference between targets of gossip described as posing a high risk of spreading the Coronavirus compared to targets of gossip described as posing a low risk of spreading the Coronavirus. Below, we outline hypotheses based on people accurately tracking infection risks in several domains.

Behavior responses to targets of gossip
1)	People want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as being actively infected with the Coronavirus more than targets of gossip described as having recovered from the Coronavirus or targets about whom no information is given about the Coronavirus.
2)	People want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
3)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.
4)	People want to punish targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
5)	
a)	Support for direct strategies (punishment) will be higher for people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 
b)	Support for indirect strategies (avoid/exclude) will be higher for people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 

Blaming targets
6)	People blame targets described as being actively infected with the Coronavirus more than targets of gossip described as having recovered from the Coronavirus or targets about whom no information is given about the Coronavirus.
7)	People blame targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
8)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to blame targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.

Emotions 
9)	People feel more disgust if the gossip target is described as actively infected with the Coronavirus than when not.	
10)	
a)	Anger will be higher for people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 
b)	Disgust will be higher for people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 

Person perception of gossip targets and senders
11)	Information about targets described as violating social distancing and the targets of that information are seen as less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy, and more dominant than other information and targets.
12)	Information about targets described as violating social distancing and the targets of that information are seen as more contagious than other information and targets.
13)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to see as contagious targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.
14)	Gossip describing a target as violating social distancing or as actively infected will be rated more negatively than other gossip.
15)	Gossip describing a target as violating social distancing or as actively infected will be perceived more as motivated by group protection than other gossip.
16)	There is a positive relationship between perceiving gossip as motivated by group protection and the warmth, morality, and competence of the sender.

Spreading gossip
17)	People are more willing to spread information about infection or social distancing violations than other information.
18)	People indicate that they were motivated to gossip by group protection more strongly when spreading information about infection or social distancing violations than other information.

Norm Perception, importance, and adherence
19)	When targets of gossip are described as violating social distancing compared to other targets, people valuing and adhering to measures more, perceive the target as less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy than people valuing and adhering to measures less.
20)	When targets of gossip are described as violating social distancing compared to other targets, people perceiving high versus low descriptive norms perceive the target less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy.

Full-factorial Between subjects design with 2 factors, each factor has 3 levels, making a total of 9 groups. 

The first factor is gossip about infection with the Coronavirus (recovered, infected, no information). The second factor is gossip about violating social distancing norms (adhered, violated, no information).

Within the four blocks that have two types of information (i.e., information on both infection with the Coronavirus and social distancing norms), participants will additionally be randomly assigned randomly to read one of two possible orders of the information.

After reading the scenario, participants answer questions about:

3) Rating the information from the gossip
4) Rating the information from the gossip with regards to the gossip target
5) Behavioral intentions towards the gossip target

7) Spreading gossip
8) Personal need for structure
9) Social value orientation
10) Questions regarding the Coronavirus
11) Manipulation checks

We will manipulate the gossip participants receive in the scenario. The gossip varies on two factors.

The first factor is gossip about infection with the Coronavirus (recovered, infected, no information). 

The second factor is gossip about violating social distancing norms (adhered, violated, no information).
See attachment (Gossip_COVID19_variables.xlsx) for an overview of all measures.

See attachment (Gossip_COVID19_variables.xlsx) for an overview of all measures. All combined measures will be created by summing items and dividing by the number of items.

SVO will be combined according to Murphy et al. 2011, Personal Need for Structure will be combined according to Neuberg & Newsom, 1993 with summed scores being divided by the number of items.

(Hypotheses 1-5, 6-8, 9-10, 11-15, 17-18, 19-20) To test differences between our conditions we will use ANOVAs where continuous dependent variables are predicted by a factor representing coronavirus related gossip content (1 = Recovered from Coronavirus, 2 = infected with Coronavirus, 3 = no information) and a factor representing coronavirus related gossip content (1 = Recovered from Coronavirus, 2 = infected with Coronavirus, 3 = no information) as well as their interaction. When including continuous covariates, we will use ANCOVA including interactions between covariates and factors where necessary.

(Hypothesis 16) When testing models involving continuous dependent and independent variables we use linear regression models (OLS). If including the conditions,  we will make dummy codes for the condition variables with no information as the reference category.

q18.value: To test for the effect of our gossip conditions in regression analyses, we will make dummy codes for the condition variables with no information as the reference category.

q19.value: We adapt the standard p < .05 criterion to control for multiple testing using a Bonferroni correction. As we conduct 22 tests, we will use a criterion of p < 0.00227273 (0.05/22). We will use this to determine if ANOVA and regression results are statistically significant. For ANOVA, we will use post-hoc tests using a Bonferroni correction to adjust for multiple comparisons.

q22.value:
Explorative
1)	We will further explore the relationship between how participants want receivers of their spread gossip to behave and reactions to the scenario. We will test whether these intentions match the intention attributed to the original received gossip and whether attributes of the information or the target influence these prescribed intentions. 
2)	We will explore whether the gossip manipulation influences descriptive norms of adherence to measures as well as valuing and adhering to these norms. 
3)	We will exploratively test the relationship between gossip content and reactions to the scenario and gossip motives, including other motives than group protection. 
4)	We will explore the relationships between individual differences (epistemic motivation/personal need for structure and social value orientation) and gossip content, reactions to the scenario, descriptive norms of adherence to measures as well as valuing and adhering to measures, and attitudes towards the Coronavirus. 
5)	We will explore differences between wanting to interact face-to-face and via the telephone or internet with gossip targets depending on gossip content. 
6)	We will explore relationships between gossip content, reactions to the scenario, attitudes towards the Coronavirus, and perceptions of the veracity of gossip. 
7)	We will explore behavioral intentions to help in addition to avoid/exclude, gossip, and punish to further investigate strategies to respond to gossip targets. 
8)	We will explore whether the relationship between perceived risk/impact of the Coronavirus as well as norms about the Coronavirus and the support for behavioral strategies is explained by emotions and whether this depends on gossip content. 
9)	We will explore whether the relationship between perceived risk/impact of the Coronavirus and the support for behavioral strategies is explained by perceptions of target contagiousness and whether this depends on gossip content.  
10)	We will explore relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, education, and employment status), reactions to the scenario, descriptive norms for adherence to measures, valuing and adhering to measures, and attitudes towards the Coronavirus. As part of this, we will code for the Coronavirus policy taken at the state level and explore differences between states.

registration_responses.q2:
If people accurately track infection risks, we would expect people to react most negatively to targets of gossip described as posing a high risk of spreading the Coronavirus (actively infected with the coronavirus and/or violating social distancing) compared to targets of gossip described as posing a low risk of spreading the Coronavirus (having recovered from the coronavirus and/or adhering to social distancing). However, if people do not accurately track infection risk (e.g., bias against recovered targets of gossip, overestimating risks), we expect no difference between targets of gossip described as posing a high risk of spreading the Coronavirus compared to targets of gossip described as posing a low risk of spreading the Coronavirus. Below, we outline hypotheses based on people accurately tracking infection risks in several domains.

Behavior responses to targets of gossip
1)	People want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as being actively infected with the Coronavirus more than targets of gossip described as having recovered from the Coronavirus or targets about whom no information is given about the Coronavirus.
2)	People want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
3)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to want to avoid/exclude targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.
4)	People want to punish targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
5)	
a)	Support for direct strategies (punishment) will be higher for people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 
b)	Support for indirect strategies (avoid/exclude) will be higher for people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 

Blaming targets
6)	People blame targets described as being actively infected with the Coronavirus more than targets of gossip described as having recovered from the Coronavirus or targets about whom no information is given about the Coronavirus.
7)	People blame targets of gossip described as violating social distancing more than targets of gossip described as adhering to social distancing or targets about whom no information is given about social distancing.
8)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to blame targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.

Emotions 
9)	People feel more disgust if the gossip target is described as actively infected with the Coronavirus than when not.	
10)	
a)	Anger will be higher for people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 
b)	Disgust will be higher for people perceiving low risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) compared to people perceiving high risk/impact of the Coronavirus (for self or others) when the target is described as violating social distancing compared to when not. 

Person perception of gossip targets and senders
11)	Information about targets described as violating social distancing and the targets of that information are seen as less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy, and more dominant than other information and targets.
12)	Information about targets described as violating social distancing and the targets of that information are seen as more contagious than other information and targets.
13)	We expect the social distancing information and the Coronavirus information to interact such that people are most likely to see as contagious targets of gossip described as actively infected with the Coronavirus and violating social distancing followed by targets of gossip described as only infected or only violating social distancing, in turn followed by targets described with the other possible information.
14)	Gossip describing a target as violating social distancing or as actively infected will be rated more negatively than other gossip.
15)	Gossip describing a target as violating social distancing or as actively infected will be perceived more as motivated by group protection than other gossip.
16)	There is a positive relationship between perceiving gossip as motivated by group protection and the warmth, morality, and competence of the sender.

Spreading gossip
17)	People are more willing to spread information about infection or social distancing violations than other information.
18)	People indicate that they were motivated to gossip by group protection more strongly when spreading information about infection or social distancing violations than other information.

Norm Perception, importance, and adherence
19)	When targets of gossip are described as violating social distancing compared to other targets, people valuing and adhering to measures more, perceive the target as less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy than people valuing and adhering to measures less.
20)	When targets of gossip are described as violating social distancing compared to other targets, people perceiving high versus low descriptive norms perceive the target less moral, less warm, less competent, less trustworthy.

attributes.title: Digital health competencies for primary healthcare professionals: A scoping review protocol
attributes.description: Digital technologies have already opened wide possibilities for shaping the future of primary healthcare, by allowing people to manage their health more effectively, improving the diagnosing of diseases, and monitoring the impact of policies, just to name a few examples. However, for primary healthcare systems to be able to take full advantage of these technologies, a capable, digitally literate workforce is necessary. What is not fully understood is which digital health competencies (DHC) are necessary for primary care (PC) providers and health workers to possess in order to implement and utilize digital health in PC. This knowledge hinges on a variety of factors including the type of technologies used in PC, the type of health worker, and how technologically advanced is the context and setting of the PC in question. This scoping review aims to provide a summarized overview of the context, healthcare worker, technologies and possibly evidence regarding digital health competencies in primary care to try to identify a set of generic primary care digital health technologies that every primary care provider should have.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Document did not attach to the submission

summary.value: This registration contains a protocol for a scoping review on digital health competencies for primary healthcare professionals
